  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Customer heard a loud pop from his backpack that was stored underneath his seat . Customer discovered that his vape pen had exploded and was smoldering in the backpack . Fully boarded aircraft was deplaned as smoke was coming from the backpack . Law Enforcement, TSA, and the Fire Department arrived to aksess the event. Fire department personnel and authorities inspected the passenger's bag, confiscated the vape pen, and cleared the passenger of any security concerns. The item was placed in a Port Authority ARFF TCB for removal from the aircraft . There has been some social media activity related to this event . No aircraft damage or passenger injuries reported

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal NAT experienced a UN1219 Isopropyl Alcohol 99% release from (2) 55-gallon metal drums. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct onsite cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 50-gallons of product released to a 20’ x 8’ area of the trailer floor due to a forklift puncture. Absorbents were deployed and worked into the impacted area. Each drum that was damaged was containerized into a 65-gallon metal overpack along with the impacted absorbents. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report I-2024100112
item.description:
Report I-2024100112

Identified by scraper @ 2024-10-18T09:15:07+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-09-21
  • City: ALBANY
  • State: OR
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: TEAM LEGACY INC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Tank truck was being loaded with 45,000 lbs of formaldehyde distillate(13% concentration). Toward the end of loading, a high-level probe should have stopped the pump and prevented over-filling of the truck. The probe was tripped, but the automatic valve responded more slowly than optimal resulting in a spill of about 10 gallons(100-lbs) that flowed down the side of the truck on to the truck loading pad, and then toward the secondary'containment ditch to the east of the pad. The truck and loading pad were washed down with water Into the containment ditch. From there, it drained into a sump and was conveyed by an in-place submersible pump to a recycle storage tank. Investigation found that the high-level probe triggered immediately on contact with the solution, but that the automatic valve closed slowly, and that the truck tank had a taller than usual dome-lid extension.

item.title: Report I-2024100070
item.description:
Report I-2024100070

Identified by scraper @ 2024-10-18T09:15:07+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-09-12
  • City: KANSAS CITY
  • State: MO
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: THE KANSAS CITY SOUTHERN RAILWAY
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 10000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: At 17:03 on 9/12/2024, ISO tank CXTU 101946 was reported Ieaking at the Kansas City Southern(DBA CPKC) IFG intermodal ramp located in Kansas City, MO. CPKC Hazmat Department mobilized to the ramp, along with a response contractor, to mitigate the release. Upon arrival, responders found all security seals in place. A small stream of liquid was emanating from the bottom outlet valve secondary closure cap, which was found hand tight. The primary closure"butterfly" valve was found slightly open. Additionally, the Internal bottom outlet valve's security seal was applied in such a way as to prevent the valve from fully closing. The crew tightened the secondary closure cap on the bottom outlet valve and secured the primary closure"butterfly" valve to stop the release. Due to the nature of the product, responders elected to make shipper notification and request permission to remove the security seals in order to determine the extent of the product lost. On 9/13/2024, permission was received from the shipper to remove the security seals. The crew returned to IFG to complete investigation. Upon return, the manway was opened to inspect outage on CXTU101946. All manway bolts were found loose. The Iadlng outage was approximately 2 feet. Estimate for Iading release is 40 gallons. The secondary closure cap was removed and found with a defective gasket. Responders replaced the gasket. The cap was installed tool tight and security seal installed in the closed position. Also, the internal bottom outlet valve security seal that was holding the valve in the partially open position was removed and a new security seal was properly installed holding the valve In the closed position. No security seals were removed from the butterfly valve, but an additional security seal was properly installed to hold this valve in the closed position. Once secured, CXTU101946 was released back into transportation. Additional DOT Cause Code: What Failed: 121, How Failed: 308, Cause of Failure: 508. File Note: Item 19-the quantity released was estimated based on the best Information available at the time of filing. This shipment was offered as a'bulk' shipment, aka one car loads therefore the exact amount offered in this package is not known to the carrier. This carrier does not have access to mass balance data which can exactly quantify this value.

item.title: Report I-2024100113
item.description:
Report I-2024100113

Identified by scraper @ 2024-10-18T09:15:07+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-09-10
  • City: Milwaukee
  • State: WI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: SOO LINE RAILROAD COMPANY(DBA CANADIAN PACIFIC KANSAS CITY RAILROAD)
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 10000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: File Note: Item 19-the quantity released was estimated based on the best information available at the time of filing. This shipment was offered as a'bulk' shipment, aka one car load, therefore the exact amount offered in this package is not known to the carrier. This carrier does not have access to mass balance data which can exactly quantify this value. On September 10, 2024, Daniel Perkins, FRA Hazmat Inspector, conducted an inspection at the CPKC Muskego Yard in Milwaukee, Wisconsin. During inspection of tank car TILX 318532, Mr. Perkins observed wetness inside the interior of the protective housing. The wetness evaporated instantly. Further examination revealed that that four of four liquid valve flange nuts were loose which allowed for vapor to release from the assembly. A CPKC Contractor responded to the incident and was able to tighten the fiange nuts, stopping the leak.

  • Description: The driver returned to the facility and was unloading his van trailer of all waste drums and totes. He went to move one of the 275 gallon totes and pulled too far into the tote and the forklift forks struck a drum behind lhe tote puncturing that drum causing it to leak. The driver as well as our warehouse associates quickly and safely acted to tum the drum on its side to limit the amount of liquid that leaked out- approximately 15 gallons. Speedi dry as well as absorbent pads were placed in the trailer to contain the spill. The drum was placed into and overpack drum and all the solid debris was scooped up and drummed as well.

item.title: Report E-2024100398
item.description:
Report E-2024100398

Identified by scraper @ 2024-10-18T06:17:57+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-10-15
  • City: GILBERT
  • State: SC
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: BARNES OIL AND PROPANE INC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 75000
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: On October 15th 2024 between the hours of 13:00 and 14:00 the driver loaded 7,500 gallons of clear diesel fuel into truck number 60, trailer number 139 at the Kinder Morgan fuel Terminal in North Augusta, SC. The driver left Kinder Morgan headed towards Columbia on I-20 and got off the interstate on exit 22 which is HWY #1. The driver traveled down #1 Hwy until he got to Chinquapin Road in Monetta and turned right. Chinquapin Rd turned into Two Notch Road which is in Leesville SC. The driver made a right turn onto Pond Branch and proceeded towards exit 44. The driver came over the bridge slowing down so that he would be able to make the turn. The driver stated he didn’t feel like he was speeding making the turn, but he never looked at the speedometer. The driver made his turn, and the truck proceeded to lay over on its side. The Lexington County Fire Service responded to the scene. The rollover resulted in approximately 1500 gallons of ULSD being released on to the ground. The spilt fuel was recovered/remediated by Republic Services. The remaining product was pumped from the rolled over trailer to a trailer brought on scene by Barnes Oil & Propane Representatives.

  • Description: AT THE UPS FACILITY IN COLOGNE, GERMANY, ONE LITHIUM BATTERY AIR PACKAGE BEING HELD SINCE 01-SEPTEMBER-2024 WAS FOUND TO HAVE TWO VISIBLE BURN MARKS ON THE BOTTOM OF THE PACKAGE. THE PACKAGE HAD BEEN STORED FOR SEVERAL WEEKS DUE TO MISSING CUSTOMS CLEARANCE AND WAS PLANNED TO BE RETURNED TO THE SHIPPER IN HONG KONG UNDER RETURN TRACKING NUMBER 1ZHLDRTS6620170846. THE INCIDENT PACKAGE WAS MARKED AND LABELED AS UN3480, LITHIUM ION BATTERIES, PACKING INSTRUCTION 965. THE PACKAGE HAD AN IATA SHIPPERS DECLARATION AND HAD PREVIOUSLY PASSED AN ACCEPTANCE AUDIT IN HONG KONG ON 30-AUGUST-2024. INNER CONTENT INSPECTION REVEALS ONE XH2000 JOYCUBE POWER STATION 2150.4 WATT HOURS WITH EVIDENCE OF SCORTCH MARKS. AT THE TIME OF DISCOVERY AND INSPECTION NO ACTIVE THERMAL EVENT WAS OBSERVED.

  • City: PHOENIX

  • Description: On October 7, 2024, four (4) 5-gallon pails of Zep Morado Super Cleaner were crushed and released approximately one and a half (1.5) cups of product to the dock floor and cardboard. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from GrayMar Environmental Services (GES) to remediate the site. GES personnel deployed granular absorbents to the Zep Morado Super Cleaner-impacted dock floor and cardboard and swept them in with hand tools. All spent absorbents were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum, and four (4) 5-gallon pails of Zep Morado Super Cleaner were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum for transport and disposal.

item.title: Report I-2024100095
item.description:
Report I-2024100095

Identified by scraper @ 2024-10-18T06:17:57+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-10-01
  • City: Port Allen
  • State: LA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: SOUTHEASTERN FREIGHT LINES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 10/1/2024 a Southeastern Freight Lines BTR associate was attempting to load 6 totes on pro# 374199108 into trailer 537530, located in dock door 58. At approximately 05:50, during the loading process, one of the placard/label frames on one of the totes caught the wall. The label frame was bent, ripped off of the tote, and punctured the 275-gallon tote. The tote immediately started Ieaking from the side. Approximately 10-gallons leaked inside of the trailer& on the dock. The tote was manuvered immediately& containment measures were performed to assure no further Ieakage. None of the chemical(UN3264) spilled onto the ground, or near water/drainage systems. Southeastern Freight Lines Safety was contacted at approximately 06:00. Safety contacted Hazmat 1, and Hazmat 1 contacted E3/OMI Environmental Services. Louisiana State Police arrived at approximately 08:00. E3/OMI arrived at approximately 09:00. Transfer& clean up procedures concluded at approximately 13:20. E3/OMI will return once approval has been received to retrieve for disposal the following: 1- Full tote(UN3264) 2- Empty Totes(Non-Hazardous/Residue)' 1- 55-Gallon Drum(Non-Hazardous)

  • Carrier/Reporter: VEOLIA ES TECHNICAL SOLUTIONS, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: During a routine vehicle inspection at the job site, Veolia employees discovered paint dripping from a drum. Upon investigation, they determined that the leaking drum had been collected from a previous customer, Hentzen. The employees located the source of the leak, which was coming from the top of the drum. After a thorough inspection, the seal was identified as the cause of the problem. The employees theorized that the truck's vibration during transport had caused the paint to seep through the faulty top seal. Fortunately, the spill was contained within the truck, and no paint had leaked outside while the vehicle was in motion. The team took immediate action to address the situation. They contained the spill and overpacked the drum, along with all materials used in the cleanup process. This prompt response ensured that the incident was managed efficiently and safely, minimizing any potential environmental impact or further complications.

item.description:
Report X-2024101009

Identified by scraper @ 2024-10-17T09:14:53+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-10-10
  • City: NEW YORK
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: AN AIR PACKAGE AT THE DELIVERY DESTINATION CENTER NEEDED ADDITIONAL TAPING DUE TO THE SEAL OF ONE END OF THE BOX BROKE OPEN. WHILE RETAPING WE DISCOVERED IPHONES WERE INSIDE THE UNMARKED PACKAGE. FULL CONTENT INSPECTION REVEALS 17 USED IPHONES. AT LEAST FOUR OF THE IPHONES POWER ON WITH A LOW BATTERY STATUS. THE ADDITIONAL IPHONES DO NOT HAVE ENOUGH CHARGE TO POWER ON. THE CELL PHONES WERE INDIVIDUALLY WRAPPED IN BUBBLE WRAP. THEY WERE THEN PLACED IN GROUPS OF THREE ON BUBBLE WRAP AND FOLDED A FEW TIMES REPEATING UNTIL ALL WERE WRAPPED INTO ONE BUNDLE. THERE ARE NO DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTER BOX. PRIOR TO THE UNDECLARED DISCOVERY, THE PACKAGE WAS FLOWN ON UPS AIRCRAFT.

  • Description: On October 4, 2024, one (1) 55-gallon drum of sulfuric acid was damaged due to unknown causes and released approximately five (5) gallons of product to the trailer interior, tires, concrete, and facility processing drain. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Green Site Services Group, Inc. (GSSG) to remediate the impacted site. The damaged drum was placed into one (1) 95-gallon overpack drum for transport and disposal. A neutralizing agent was deployed to the impacted areas. Once the area was properly neutralized, the crew deployed soda ash to the impacted areas and worked them in with hand tools. The impacted material was collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum for transport and disposal.

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 9/25/2024 at approximately 1030, Dangerous Goods Administration received a call from Employee 957951 at the ramp facility in Sacramento, reporting a dangerous goods spill. The shipment consisted of one fiberboard box, containing two fiberboard boxes with a fire extinguisher in each inner box. The shipment was discovered showing a powder residue on the outer package and on the aircraft floor. Further investigation revealed that the shipment contained fire extinguishers that were missing the secure pin. Additionally, the package was not prepared in accordance with IATA regulations, missing the required markings, labeling, packaging and paperwork on the outermost pacakge. The shipment is being held, pending in FAA investigation.

  • City: Charleston
  • State: SC
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CSX TRANSPORTATION, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 09/20/2024, at 0857 hours, CSX personnel reported UTLX 208840, a loaded tank car containing Alcohols, N.O.S., leaking from top of the tank car. The car was isolated and the shipper, Poet Bioprocessing, was notified via Ambipar (Report #20240920-01-02787). CSX Senior Manager of Hazardous Materials Rob James responded to the scene and found five of eight manway cover bolts less than tool tight. Mr. James inspected the car to ensure there were no notable defects to the manway cover, gasket, or nozzle, and secured all manway cover bolts tool tight to secure the product release. The issue identified and corrective actions were communicated to the shipper’s representative- Jared Ayers (316-213-2805). Upon proper securement the car was released for transportation.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 8000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XTM experienced a UN3266 PI-2100 release from a 55-gallon poly drum. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 55-gallons of product released to a 15’ x 20’ area of the concrete dock floor. Prior to their arrival, XPO placed wood chips and absorbents down to contain the release. The damaged drum was placed into an 85-gallon poly overpack. Absorbents were then worked into the impacted area. All impacted absorbents, wood chips, cleanup debris, and the impacted pallet were containerized into 2 flex bins and (3) 55-gallon poly drums. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 11000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On October 10, 2024, at 1154 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Landstar personnel in Euclid, OH regarding the release of Paraformaldehyde Prills 91-93%. Contractors were dispatched to the site to perform all onsite clean-up activities. Upon arrival, contractors confirmed the release of 150 lbs of Paraformaldehyde Prills 91-93% (UN2213, 4.1, III) from (3) bags onto the trailer floor. The release was reportedly due to impact from pallets during loading, affecting multiple areas in the trailer. No drains or waterways were impacted by the release. The contractors collected the release with the proper PPE. All waste generated from addressing this release was containerized in (2) 55-gallon DF, which were then taken off site by contractors for proper disposal.

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 10/6/2024 at approximately 2300, Dangerous Goods Administration received a call from Hub Security in Indianapolis, reporting undeclared dangerous goods. The shipment consisted of 4 wooden pallets, each supporting a large fiberboard gaylords, containing used cell phones and cell phone batteries. The shipment was discovered by security after collapsing under the weight of the inner contents, revealing the cell phones. The shipments were not prepared in accordance with IATA Regulations, missing the required markings, labeling, and paperwork. The shipment was held for the FAA investigation.

  • Description: On October 3, 2024, one (1) 50-pound bag of UN1823 was torn during unloading and released approximately two (2) pounds of product to the loading dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Hull's Environmental Services (HES) to remediate the impacted site. HES deployed and absorbents and utilized hand tools to remediate the area. All impacted debris was collected and containerized into one (1) 5-gallon bucket for disposal. HES removed the one (1) damaged bag of sodium hydroxide powder and placed it into a 55-gallon drum for disposal.
